div.head:
Embleme 40. Of the Secrets of Nature.
Of two waters make one, and that will be the water of Sanctity.

lg.l: Two streaming fountains here you may behold,
One with hott water, but the other cold:
That's calldcalled the Boy's, but this the Virgins Spring,
Joyne them, that they may be one onely thing:
This river will participate of both,

div.head: Discourse 40.
div.ab:
The miracles of waters are soeso many and soeso great, as scarce to be-
comprehended in a large volume, concerning which severall authors-
have here and there treated: But above all the two Philosophicall wa
ters are celebrated with that name, because they doe as it were not one
ly æmulateemulate, but allso exceed the virtues and propertyes of all the rest.-
The rivers Sybaris, Axus of Macedonia, and Melas of BœotiaBoeotia make-
Cattle blacke, if they drinke thereof; but the rivers Crathis, Clitummus
of Mevania, and Cephisus make blacke Cattle white. The waters of-
Sinnessa in the country of Campania takes away barrennessebarrenness from-
both sexes. The river Afrodisius makes women barren: Cabura a foun
taine of Mesopotamia hath water of a sweet smell; The water of Any
ger in Peloponnesus stinks very much: The fountaine of Jupiter Ham
mon is cold in the day time, hott by night, and morning and evening-
luke-warme by turnes. Wee need not insist upon others, all things even
contrary one to the other are performd by the Philosophers waters. Of
which Sayth Lully in his booke of the Quintessence, distin: 3. of ince
ration; And soeso there is a twofold consideration in the act, that is, of
the single nature of one metall to make two contrary liquours in the-
composition; one, which hath a fixing, congealing, and hardninghardening vir
tue, and the other, which is volatile, unfixed, and soft. But that se
cond liquor is hardened, fixed, and congealed by the first: from both-
which liquors results one stone congealed, fixed, and hardened, which
hath the virtue of congealing not a thing congealed, to harden a thing
mollifyed, and to mollify a hard thing: From which it is evident,-
what those two waters are, and why to be reduced into one water:-
For the Stone is called water, because fusible, and on the contrary,
water stone, because frangible: But these waters are drawne out of-
different places, sometimes in a long tract, as may be seen at Rome-
about Aqua Virginis, and other artificiall fountains, and then they-
must be mixed by conflux, that one may be made of two. For if
one be of a hott and the other of a cold virtue, being mixed together
they will acquire mixd virtues, and after a wonderfull manner re
gulate one the other: From hence are most excellent medicinall and
bath waters to be produced, which will profligate all sorts of diseases-
and maladyes, and restore a man to firme health. Nature doth in
deed by her occult artifice of composition confound and mix many-
waters in the bowells of the earth with severall virtues of Mynes, which
are wholesome and coḿodious to many sicke and infirmeinfirm persons, but
if art be added with due regiment, all evacuations being præmises and
other things to be prætermittedpretermitted, and mix those things that are to be-
mixed together, that composition will be farre more effectuall:-
Which, though it seem artificiall, is notwithstanding merely naturall,
because of things different it is made one simple homogeneous matter,
Discourse 40.
which can never be effected by art: A mixtion and confusion is indeed cau
sed by art, without the helpe of nature noe true and naturall union,-
which is made by nature alone: There is an artificiall mixtion of various-
simples in Triacle, which is performd by contrition and fermentation,-
but noe man will (except inconsiderately) affirme it to be a naturall-
composition, much lesse a homogeneous medicament: As to the artificiall
mixtion of substances it is manifest, that they doe not enter one-
into the other in the least parts, though they cannot againe be divided
and separated one from the other by the industry of man. But as to
the mixtion of all qualityes wee must enquire, whether the first Tri
acles of all Simples may be reduced not one Quintessence,and whol
or yet in their powders or substances be, as before, as accidents in a subject,
or colour in a wall; and then what is to be sayd of the second, third, and
fourth qualityes? Probable it is that all the qualityes are yet inhærentinherent
in their owne subjects, and not compounded together by a true natu
rall mixtion; otherwise, if the qualityes should relinquish their bo
dyes, there would be four Quintessences in every 2 composition 1 arti
ficiall, according to the number of the order of the qualityes, first,-
second Ct. without their bodyes, and separable; which they say
is not soeso with the coagulum of a hare, which being in flux-
by the tenuity of the blood stops and as it were coagulates it,-
but in the coagulation and concretion cuttscuts and resolves the same;
soe the operations of vinegar, lead, and many other things are con
trary according to the different use of them, because nature hath-
soe wonderfully mixed them: Soe allso hath the Philosophicall
water different and contrary virtues, because nature hath by the-
helpe of art mixed it with things contrary into one indivisible-
substance, which is nothing els but a Quintessence, in respect of-
other things to be mixed with it. . . . . . .
